title: Using the robsel package
text: First, create Erdős–Rényi graph corresponding precision matrix using igraph package. , generate data sample size \(n=3200\) using mvtnorm package
code: #ER_graph d=100 prob=0.02 set.seed(1) ER_graph = sample_gnp(n=d, p=prob, directed = FALSE, loops = F) adj_matrix_ER = as_adjacency_matrix(ER_graph, sparse=F) #Edge weights edge_weights =  matrix(runif(d*d, min=0.5, max=1), ncol=d) edge_sign =  matrix(sample(c(-1,1), size=d*d, replace=T), ncol=d) Omega = edge_weights * edge_sign Omega = Omega * as_adjacency_matrix(ER_graph, sparse=F) Omega_0 = Omega #Positive Definite procedure off_sum = rowSums(abs(Omega_0)) * 1.5 off_sum[off_sum==0] = 1 off_sum = matrix(rep(off_sum, d), ncol=d) Omega = Omega_0/off_sum Omega = (Omega + t(Omega))/2 set.seed(1) diag(Omega) = runif(d, min=1, max=1.5) Sigma = solve(Omega) sim.data <- rmvnorm(n=3200, mean=rep(0,d), sigma=Sigma)

what: Estimate of the regularization parameter for Graphical Lasso
title: Using the robsel package
text: function robsel estimates \(\lambda\), regularization parameter Graphical Lasso prespecified confidence level \(\alpha\).

what: Graphical Lasso algorithm with \(\lambda\) from Robust Selection
title: Using the robsel package
text: function robsel.glasso returns estimates sparse inverse covariance matrix using Graphical Lasso regularization parameter estimated Robust Selection

what: Using robsel with multiple prespecified significant levels
title: Using the robsel package
text: can use multiple \(\alpha\) simultaneously Robust Selection list estimated graphs contains 3 elements corresponding 3 different significant levels \(\alpha\).

what: Visualizing Graphical Lasso estimated graph tuned by robsel
title: Using the robsel package
text: can see small significant level \(\alpha = 0.05\), estimated graph robsel recovers many correct true edges contain false edge.
code: # Graph plot  #True Graph g <- make_empty_graph(n = d, directed = F) %>%     add_edges(c(t(which(adj_matrix_ER!=0,arr.ind = T)))) %>%     set_edge_attr("color", value = "black") %>%      set_edge_attr("curved", value = 0)  # RobSel Graph robsel.fit <- robsel.glasso(sim.data, alpha=0.05, penalize.diagonal=F) robsel.graph.1 <- robsel.fit$Omega[[1]] diag(robsel.graph.1) <- 0 robsel_true_index <- which((robsel.graph.1!=0 & adj_matrix_ER!=0),arr.ind = T) robsel_false_index <- which((robsel.graph.1!=0 & adj_matrix_ER==0),arr.ind = T) g.robsel.1 <- make_empty_graph(n = d, directed = F) %>%     add_edges(c(t(robsel_false_index)), color="red", curved=0) %>%      add_edges(c(t(robsel_true_index)), color="black", curved=0) # Plots par(mfrow=c(1,2), mar = c(1, 1, 1, 1)) plot(g, layout=layout.circle, vertex.color = "lightblue", vertex.label.cex=0.5, vertex.size=6, main="True graph")  plot(g.robsel.1, layout=layout.circle, vertex.color = "lightblue", vertex.label.cex=0.5, vertex.size=6, main="RobSel graph")

what: Fit Graphical Lasso with RobSel — robsel.glasso
title: Fit Graphical Lasso with RobSel — robsel.glasso
text: Fit  Graphical Lasso estimate regularization parameter Robust Selection

title: Fit Graphical Lasso with RobSel — robsel.glasso
Fit Graphical Lasso with RobSel — robsel.glasso
text: x n--p data matrix alpha Prespecified confidence level. Default 0.9 B Number bootstrap sample. Default 200 ... Optional arguments passed glasso.

title: Fit Graphical Lasso with RobSel — robsel.glasso
text: list components: alpha list prespecified confidence level lambda list estimate regularization parameter Graphical Lasso Omega list estimated inverse covariance matrix Sigma list estimated covariance matrix

title: Fit Graphical Lasso with RobSel — robsel.glasso
text: item compenent corresponds prespecified level alpha.

title: Fit Graphical Lasso with RobSel — robsel.glasso
text: P Cisneros-Velarde, Petersen S-Y Oh (2020). Distributionally Robust Formulation Model Selection Graphical Lasso. Proceedings Twenty Third International Conference Artificial Intelligence Statistics. Friedman, Jerome, Trevor Hastie, Robert Tibshirani. 'Sparse inverse covariance estimation graphical lasso.' Biostatistics 9.3 (2008): 432-441. Meinshausen, Nicolai Buhlmann, Peter. 2006. 'High-Dimensional Graphs Variable Selection Lasso.' Annals Statistics. JSTOR: 1436-1462. Witten, Daniela M, Friedman, Jerome H, Simon, Noah. 2011. 'New Insights Faster computations Graphical Lasso.' Journal Computation Graphical Statistics. Taylor Francis: 892-900.

title: Fit Graphical Lasso with RobSel — robsel.glasso
code: set.seed(17) library(robsel) x <-matrix(rnorm(50*20),ncol=20)  #Use Graphical Lasso with estimate regularization parameter lambda from RobSel fit <- robsel.glasso(x = x, alpha = 0.9, B = 200)

title: Robust Selection — robsel
text: Robust Selection algorithm estimation regularization parameter Graphical Lasso

title: Robust Selection — robsel
text: x n--p data matrix alpha Prespecified confidence level. Default 0.9 B Number bootstrap sample. Default 200

title: Robust Selection — robsel
text: lambda Estimation regularization parameter Graphical Lasso. vector lambda return 1 value alpha provided.

title: Robust Selection — robsel
text: P Cisneros-Velarde, Petersen S-Y Oh (2020). Distributionally Robust Formulation Model Selection Graphical Lasso. Proceedings Twenty Third International Conference Artificial Intelligence Statistics.

title: Robust Selection — robsel
code: set.seed(17) library(robsel) x <-matrix(rnorm(50*20),ncol=20)  #Compute estimation of lambda at confidence level alpha lambda <- robsel(x = x, alpha = 0.9, B = 200)
